hints.label: prop-ig-homotopy-classes
hints.title: IG Homotopy Classes
hints.content:
1471: :label: prop-ig-homotopy-classes
1472: 
1473: Two micro-states $z, z'$ can have identical $(x, v)$ but different IG neighborhoods $\mathcal{N}_{\text{IG}}(z) \neq \mathcal{N}_{\text{IG}}(z')$. These lead to different υ-states if the IG structure affects the macro-future.
1474: 
1475: **Homotopy class perspective:** The υ-machine refines the causal states by the **homotopy class** of IG connections. Two states are in the same υ-state only if their IG neighborhoods are topologically equivalent (same connectivity pattern).

hints.label: thm-upsilon-machine-minimality
hints.title: υ-Machine Minimality
hints.content:
1485: :label: thm-upsilon-machine-minimality
1486: 
1487: The υ-machine $(\Sigma_\upsilon, T_\upsilon)$ is the **minimal refinement** of the micro-ε-machine that predicts the macro-future.
1488: 
1489: Formally, for any other partition $\mathcal{P}$ of micro-states such that:
1490: 
1491: $$
1492: P(\overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}} \mid [\overleftarrow{z}]_{\mathcal{P}}) = P(\overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}} \mid Z = z)
1493: 
1494: $$
1495: 
1496: we have $|\Sigma_\upsilon| \leq |\mathcal{P}|$ (the υ-machine has fewer or equal states).

hints.label: cor-mutual-information-characterization
hints.title: Mutual Information Characterization
hints.content:
1502: :label: cor-mutual-information-characterization
1503: 
1504: The statistical complexity of the υ-machine is:
1505: 
1506: $$
1507: C_\upsilon = I(\overleftarrow{Z} ; \overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}}) - I(\overleftarrow{\tilde{Z}} ; \overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}})
1508: 
1509: $$
1510: 
1511: **Interpretation:** $C_\upsilon$ measures the information in the micro-past that is relevant for the macro-future but not captured by the macro-past. This quantifies the "hidden variables" that closure theory aims to minimize.
